user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_uio_dev_bind:
```c
static int metal_uio_dev_bind(struct linux_device *ldev,
			      struct linux_driver *ldrv)
{
	struct sysfs_attribute *attr;
	int result;

	if (strcmp(ldev->sdev->driver_name, ldrv->drv_name) == 0)
		return 0;

	if (strcmp(ldev->sdev->driver_name, SYSFS_UNKNOWN) != 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_INFO, "device %s in use by driver %s\n",
			  ldev->dev_name, ldev->sdev->driver_name);
		return -EBUSY;
	}

	attr = sysfs_get_device_attr(ldev->sdev, "driver_override");
	if (!attr) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "device %s has no override\n",
			  ldev->dev_name);
		return -errno;
	}

	result = sysfs_write_attribute(attr, ldrv->drv_name,
				       strlen(ldrv->drv_name));
	if (result) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "failed to set override on %s\n",
			  ldev->dev_name);
		return -errno;
	}
	ldev->override = attr;

	attr = sysfs_get_driver_attr(ldrv->sdrv, "bind");
	if (!attr) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "driver %s has no bind\n", ldrv->drv_name);
		return -ENOTSUP;
	}

	result = sysfs_write_attribute(attr, ldev->dev_name,
				       strlen(ldev->dev_name));
	if (result) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "failed to bind %s to %s\n",
			  ldev->dev_name, ldrv->drv_name);
		return -errno;
	}

	metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "bound device %s to driver %s\n",
		  ldev->dev_name, ldrv->drv_name);

	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_uio_dev_bind:
struct linux_device {
	struct metal_device		device;
	char				dev_name[PATH_MAX];
	char				dev_path[PATH_MAX];
	char				cls_path[PATH_MAX];
	metal_phys_addr_t		region_phys[METAL_MAX_DEVICE_REGIONS];
	struct linux_driver		*ldrv;
	struct sysfs_device		*sdev;
	struct sysfs_attribute		*override;
	int				fd;
}
...
struct linux_driver {
	const char		*drv_name;
	const char		*mod_name;
	const char		*cls_name;
	struct sysfs_driver	*sdrv;
	int			(*dev_open)(struct linux_bus *lbus,
					    struct linux_device *ldev);
	void			(*dev_close)(struct linux_bus *lbus,
					     struct linux_device *ldev);
	void			(*dev_irq_ack)(struct linux_bus *lbus,
					     struct linux_device *ldev,
					     int irq);
	int			(*dev_dma_map)(struct linux_bus *lbus,
						struct linux_device *ldev,
						uint32_t dir,
						struct metal_sg *sg_in,
						int nents_in,
						struct metal_sg *sg_out);
	void			(*dev_dma_unmap)(struct linux_bus *lbus,
						struct linux_device *ldev,
						uint32_t dir,
						struct metal_sg *sg,
						int nents);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
static int metal_uio_dev_bind(struct linux_device *ldev,
			      struct linux_driver *ldrv)
explanation: I did not select other fragments for investigation because they do not present opportunities to apply Rule 8.13: - The pointer parameter 'ldev' (and members thereof) is written to (ldev->override is assigned), so it cannot be made a pointer-to-const. - The local variable 'attr' and the attribute objects obtained are used with write operations (sysfs_write_attribute), so they must be mutable pointers and cannot be const-qualified. - The member drv_name in struct linux_driver is already declared as const char * (see provided definitions), so uses of that member where it already has const qualification are not candidates. - Character arrays such as ldev->dev_name are not pointer types and thus are not relevant to Rule 8.13. - Function pointer members in struct linux_driver are not appropriate to be made pointer-to-const in this context. Therefore the listed fragments are the primary places where a pointer could reasonably be const-qualified (for example making the driver parameter a pointer-to-const), and other code lines do not warrant further investigation under Rule 8.13.
